posts.content:
I have taken a second (or third?) look on this class combo and builds like Ko'di Blademaster. I also found one of my own old attempts at building such a character somewhere on my hard drive.
I was aiming for a str based lvl 40 build with dev crit for pvm.
Most builds I find in the seach engine have 6-12 levels of fighter, many have 6-9 levels of monk and most go heavy on wm with 19-25 levels for high AB.

So far I have toyed with a fighter 6/ monk 12/ wm 22 spread, taking fighter 4/monk 6/wm 10 pre epic.
stats:
str 14 (30)
dex 14
con 14
int 14
wis 14
cha 8

AB: 47
Weapon of choice: greatsword
going in robes for stealth, speed and higher AC with dex and wis buffs

I seek advice on the following:

How much monk pre epic?
Pre epic monk gives better saves, quicker access to monk feats like evasion, cleave and IKD, but cost AB

How much monk altogether?
6 for IKD?
9 for improved evasion and more speed?
12 for even better speed, AC , SR etc?

How much Fighter?
11+ for max BAB pre epic and EWS?
Less to give room for more monk or WM goodies?

Full plate vs monk robes: Plate has a fixed AC, robes give better speed and stealth, dex and wis buffs can give robes better AC than full plate.

Kama (single wield) vs greatsword: (I thought this one was a no brainer in favor of the greatsword until i took a closer look at the numbers)
Both have same average AB per attack: eg: 47/42/37/32 vs. 47/44/41/38/35/32 with an average of 39.5 for both
Greatsword has better damage output per hit: 2d6 +1.5x str mod+EWS vs. kama: 1d6 + str mod +EWS
Kama has 50% more attacks/ round
Kama starts to get better damage output per round on ordinary hits when you factor in EWS and even better with weapon enchantments
Greatsword is better at piercing DR
Greatsword has 50%* bigger threat range, but kama has 50% more attempts to land a critical hit/round
(*factoring in IC and ki critical)

posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote:

I do not have any specific pw or sp mod in mind for the build yet.
Average AB is indeed a very rough way to measure hit chances with many pitfalls. I guess my point was that they both start with 47 and end at 32 making them look roughly equal.
Like you say, an exact damage comparison will be complex factoring in hit ratio and crit % vs different ACs. Flurry complicates things further since it both gives an extra attack, and lowers the AB of all attacks. Dual wield is also more complex to calculate and also takes another feat selection.
It's not trivial, but it also is not that complex. One needs to build an excel sheet and run the numbers (and formulas). This is something I did for kamas vs unarmed in a monk build for example, which shows that in a mid magic environment with +5 enhancements and extra elemental damage (and without a further extra damage property for gloves to compensate for the fact they get a simple AB enhancement vs an attack (AB+damage) one of ordinary melee weapons) kama generally gives a higher damage output but vs one specific AB-AC value IIRC (might be 2 values).
But before someone tries to calculate this, I just want to say that even a single kama looks far better than I had thought in comparison with "the mighty" greatsword.
Without having run the numbers, that should generally be true. It's difficult to give up kama in a monk build on the basis of running the damage output per round numbers, but that cannot be the only factor to consider. One should go for what one likes best, even on the basis of simple "stylish" preferences. A greatsword wielding monk can be cool.
AC in robes can be quite ok if you start out with dex 14 and wis 14 (rather than 13 and 8) and can buff them, at least with potions and have access to some dex/wis items. A fighter/monk/wm will not have uncanny dodge though.
The 14/14 ability spread will come at the expense of something else: what will it be, int, con or str? (in my builds I went for 15/8 in one case, because of dual wielding requirements and 14/14 in the other) AC can be improved but at a cost, as usual. Also, those buffs you "plan" upon are of an easily dispellable nature and they would apply also to another monkish build with a higher starting AC; what I mean, is that you are "lagging" behind AC wise because of the class spread, fundamentally, if going for robes. If not going for robes, then I'd say there are better choices than monk for a greatsword dev critter since you lose a lot of monk boni for going armored and not unarmed/kama. FTR/Rogue/WM, as uninventive as it sounds, would be a better way to get your dev critting greatsword build.

Here's one that is over on the other side of the spectrum w/higher AC. Much reduced AB but with monk progression most attacks will begin to coincide with a greatsword version like you are considering (haven't tested this but I think it gets the full 10 APR when flurried). I don't like any melee fighter without Blind Fight so passed up Toughness. Also, you could gain Toughness back in epic by going with Ftr 14/Monk 19 but lose 1 AC and a few saves. I don't know what other feat in epic that would be all that useful TBH. You could shift 2 start pts from WIS to CON and then with Toughness (by virtue of Mnk 19/Ftr 14) end up with 480 HP but lose 2 AC in the process. You hadn't mentioned the HPs in your original post so I don't know how concerned you are about that issue.

Of course, you could go the non-kama route but lose most of the boni of monking it.

Note: This is provided simply as a means for comparison as the AB seems a bit low to me, though the mundane DC is not bad @38. However, IMO WM is either WM 7 or WM 13+ (best: WM 19+ for main AB boosting & feats) at the cost of AC, move speed and saves. Somewhere in the middle perhaps there may a compromise that will service your needs.

That covers all your melee combat feats taken as bonus WM feats, then you can use regular ones for stat increases.

For the record Fighter 8 Monk 10 WM 22 would grant you the +1 AB (going Monk 4 Fighter 6 WM 10 pre-epic you gain 1 BAB) and also 1 AC, but not the bonus feat (not in epics, but you do get an extra fighter bonus feat pre-epic), so maybe splitting the difference is the way to go?

Good job, though.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
The advantage of going Fighter is that you can take the feats for dual-wielding AND also WS / EWS. The disadvantage is that you'll need to get at least 15 DEX for ITWF.

Going as Ranger, you can ditch dex, because the class will give you the same feats at Ranger level 9 (actually Dual-wield at 1 and ITWF at 9) even if you don't meet the DEX requirement. BUT, there's a catch! Ranger feats don't work while wearing anything heavier than a light armor, so if you ditch dex and you wear light armor, that results in VERY LOW AC. The advantage is that monks lose their stuff if they wear ANY ARMOR AT ALL, so part of the benefit of going Fighter is lost, which would be being able to go with full plate and still dual. It's just a matter of personal preference, I guess. I would go Ranger 9 Monk 9 WM 22 for +1 AB.

Take it EZ!
